Frontend Testing Recipes

by
Nouran Mahmoud

Frontend Testing became a MUST

  • Frontend development has drastically shifted into a more complex environment.

Enhance productivity by catching errors Immediately

Reduce the number of “Why isn’t this working?” phone calls and emails on Friday night.

Helpful documentation complement

While your particular application may not need to take advantage of every type of testing that exists, it’s important to know the options that are out there, what they are used for, and when it’s appropriate to use each one.

You should feel comfortable assessing which testing strategies fit best with your team and codebases.

Automated Testing Strategies

Unit Test

  • Think of it as ‘Do one thing well’ mantra
  • It is making sure individual sets of code are working as intended before building the larger feature.
  • A test suite – a grouping of tests related to a particular area of the application.

Unit Test

  • It enables you to run suites on their own. If you’re working on a new feature for an application, you don’t want to run every test during active development, as that would be time consuming.
  • Using the it function, we write the feature or piece of functionality we are testing.
  • Pure functions, Mocks (data assertions) ,and Stubs (functions return).

Example

describe("MathUtils", function() {
  var calc;
  
  //This will be called before running each spec
  beforeEach(function() {
      calc = new MathUtils();
  });
  
  describe("when calc is used to peform basic math operations", function(){
  
      //Spec for sum operation
      it("should be able to calculate sum of 3 and 5", function() {
          expect(calc.sum(3,5)).toEqual(8);
      });
      
      //Spec for multiply operation
      it("should be able to multiply 10 and 40", function() {
          expect(calc.multiply(10, 40)).toEqual(400);
      });
      
      //Spec for factorial operation for positive number
      it("should be able to calculate factorial of 9", function() {
          expect(calc.factorial(9)).toEqual(362880);
      });
      
      //Spec for factorial operation for negative number
      it("should be able to throw error in factorial operation when the number is negative", function() {
          expect(function() { 
              calc.factorial(-7)
          }).toThrowError(Error);
      });
      
  });
});

Result

Let’s Tool Up

Integration Test (REST API Testing)

  • Integration test is the phase in software testing in which individual software modules are combined and tested as a group.

Example

var frisby = require('frisby');
frisby.create('Get Brightbit Twitter feed')
  .get('https://api.twitter.com/?screen_name=brightbit')
  .expectStatus(200)
  .expectHeaderContains('content-type', 'application/json')
  .expectJSON('0', {
    place: function(val) {
      expect(val).toMatchOrBeNull("Oklahoma City, OK");
    }, // Custom matcher callback
    user: {
      verified: false,
      location: "Oklahoma City, OK",
      url: "http://brightb.it"
    }
  })
.toss();

Tools

  • Jasmine-frisby
  • Mocha + chai
  • hippie
  • Chakram

Smoking Test

  • also known as

  • End-to-End Test
  • Black Box Test
  • Acceptance Test
  • Validation Test
  • Functional Test

Smoking Test

  • The term “smoke test” comes from the olden days when if you wanted to see if a device was working, you could just plug it into the wall and if you smelled smoke, that was bad.
  • Just because all the pieces are accounted for doesn’t mean that the instructions are properly executable and will allow you to build the final model.

Smoking Test

  • Tests go through your running application and ensure designated actions, user inputs and user flows are completable and functioning
  • We’re testing to see if a particular workflow (a sign-up flow) behaves as expected when we fill in some bad information.
  • How does your user interact with your website, and what is the expected outcome of that interaction?

Example

describe("Sign Up Failure state", function () {
  it("Shouldn't allow signup with invalid information", function () {
    var page = visit("/home");
    page.fill_in("input[name='email']", "Not An Email");
    page.click("button[type=submit]");
    page.click("button[type=submit]");
    expect(page.find("#signupError").hasClass("hidden")).toBeFalsy();
  });
});

Example

cucumber-mink features
Feature: Post page

Background:
  Given I browse "http://my-app:3000/"
  
Scenario: Go on post 1
  Given I am on homepage
  When I follow "Post-1"
  Then I should be on "/post/1"
  And I should see "Post-1"

Tools

  • CucumberJS + Cucumber Mink
  • PioneerJS
  • Cypress.io

Monkey Testing

Monkey testing is a technique where the user tests the application or system by providing random inputs and checking the behavior, or seeing whether the application or system will crash.

Example

Example

Tools

  • Gremlins.js

Visual Regression

find differences game
  • This doesn’t test your code, but rather compares the rendered result of your code – your interface – with the rendered version of your application in production, staging, or a pre-changed local environment.
  • Image comparison tools then detect any differences between the two shots.
  • You’ll likely save these tests for when pieces of the interface are visually complete.

Example

casper.start("/home").then(function(){

// Initial state of form
phantomcss.screenshot("#signUpForm", "sign up form");

// Hit the sign up button (should trigger error)
casper.click("button#signUp");

// Take a screenshot of the UI component
phantomcss.screenshot("#signUpForm", "sign up form error");

// Fill in form by name attributes & submit
casper.fill("#signUpForm", {
  name: "Alicia Sedlock",
  email: "alicia@example.com"
}, true);

  // Take a second screenshot of success state
  phantomcss.screenshot("#signUpForm", "sign up form success");
});

Tools for Visual Regression

  • Wraith
  • PhantomCSS
  • Huxley
  • Resemblejs

Know your Limits

Know your Limits

  • Budget Testing is time-consuming and you should charge for it.
  • Timeline Include testing in the project’s timeline.
  • Scope Not every website needs to work on hundreds of devices

Embracing and Enforcing a Testing Culture

  • Start with known pain points
  • Make it part of the workflow
  • Don’t do everything at once
  • Revisit and review
